In order to provide a more accurate picture of traffic volumes, MDOT has developed a system that tracks the volume of vehicles that travel on Michigan roads each day. This data is used to help the agency plan and manage maintenance and construction projects, as well as make decisions about the most efficient use of road space.

How Traffic Levels Are Calculated

Traffic volumes are calculated by taking the number of vehicles in a given time period and dividing it by the total number of vehicles that travel the road during that time period. For example, if there are 1,000 vehicles on a road at 10:00 a.m. and 1,000 vehicles on the road at 10:00 p.m., the volume of traffic on the road is (1,000 ÷ 10) = 0.5.

On June 1, 1963, Interstate 5 was rerouted from its original route in the Los Angeles basin to the south and west of downtown Los Angeles. The new route, known as I-5, bypassed the cities of Glendale, Burbank, Pomona, Torrance, and Long Beach as well as the city of Santa Monica. The new route was designed to provide a more direct route for freight and passenger traffic, and to avoid the traffic congestion that had developed along the route in the 1950s and 1960s.

Construction of the new freeway began in 1963 and was completed in 1964. The freeway was named for California Governor Earl Warren, who had been instrumental in its construction. In addition to the freeway, the state also built a toll road, the Pacific Coast Highway, which ran from San Diego to Bakersfield.

Interstate 5 has served as a major thoroughfare for the transportation of goods and people since its construction. Today, it is the most heavily traveled freeway in the United States, with an average daily traffic of more than 200,000 vehicles.

Meridian, Mississippi (pop. 4,632) is a city in the Delta region of Mississippi. The city is bordered by Union, Calhoun, St. Francis, and Mississippi counties to the north, and Jackson County to the south. In the center of the city is the Mississippi River, which runs through the center of the city.

Understand [ edit ]

History [ edit ]

The Mississippi Delta region was the site of the first slave revolts in the United States, and the region's political and economic power was based on the cotton trade. As the region grew, so did the number of slaves, and by the mid-19th century, there were more than 200,000 slaves in the state.[1] During the Reconstruction era, Mississippi passed laws to emancipate slaves, but these were rarely enforced due to the power of the slaveholders. In 1867, the state of Mississippi passed the Fugitive Slave Act, which provided for the return of fugitives to their owners if they were in the state for more than 30 days, and to a maximum of one year in other states. This law was repealed in 1877, but not before it had a profound effect on the state's economy and population.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The city's former Grand Opera House was built in 1889 by two half brothers, Israel Marks and Levi Rothenberg. During its operation the opera house
reference_text: hosted many famous artists and works, the first being a German company's rendition of Johann Strauss II's " The Gypsy Baron ". After closing in the late 1920s due to the Great Depression, the opera house was abandoned for nearly 70 years. A $ 10 million grant in 2000 by the Riley Foundation, a local foundation chartered in 1998, sparked the building's restoration while $ 15 million came from a combination of city, county, and federal grants. The opera house's renovation was completed in September 2006 under the new name " Mississippi State University Riley Center for Education and Performing Arts. " The Riley Center, which includes a 950 @-@ seat auditorium for live performances, a 200 @-@ seat studio theater, and 30 @,@ 000 sq ft ( 2 @,@ 787 m2 ) of meeting space, attracts more than 60 @,@ 000 visitors to downtown Meridian annually for conferences, meetings, and performances.

This is the first step in a multi-phase project that will see the building transformed into a public plaza and open space.

The project is being spearheaded by the Friends of the Opera House, a group of community members who have been working to preserve the building since the 1970s. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Meridian is rightly considered an architectural treasure trove being one the nations most intact cities from the turn of the last century. Architecture students from around the nation and Canada
reference_text: are known to visit Meridian in groups as part of their coursework due to numerous structures in the city having been designed by noted architects. The only home in the US south designed by noted Canadian born Architect Louis S. Curtiss, famous for inventing the glass curtain wall skyscraper, is extant on Highland Park. The Frank Fort designed Threefoot Building is generally considered one of the best Art Deco skyscrapers in the US and is often compared to Detroit's famed Fisher Building. Noted California Architect Wallace Neff designed a number of homes in Meridian as well as in the Alabama Black Belt which adjoins the city across the nearby Alabama State line. He had relatives in Meridian and Selma who were executives in the then thriving railroad industry and would take commissions in the area when commissions in California were lean. His work is mostly concentrated in the lower numbered blocks of Poplar Springs Drive where his 2516 Poplar Springs Drive is often compared to the similarly designed Falcon Lair, the Beverly Hills home in Benedict Canyon of Rudolph Valentino. One Neff work was lost to an expansion of Anderson Hospital in 1990 and another in Marion Park burned in the 1950s. The Meridian Post Office with its interior done entirely of bronze and Verde marble is also noteworthy as a very fine example of the type of Post Office structures built in thriving and well to do cities in the 1920s and originally had Lalique lighting which was removed sadly during a 1960s remodeling and which are now in private residences on Poplar Springs Drive and in North Hills.

Crescent Line History

The first train to run on the Crescent line was a steam locomotive built in 1892 by the Crescent Locomotive Works (CLW). The Crescent line was the first line of its kind in the United States, and it was a huge success. By the time the line was decommissioned in the 1960s, it had carried over a million passengers.

The CLW built a second steam locomotive, the Crescent A, in 1894. The Crescent A was used for passenger service until its retirement in 1968. The Crescent A was replaced by the Crescent B, which was built in the same year. The Crescent B was retired in the mid-1970s, and the line was shut down for good in the early 1980s.

After the closure of the line, Amtrak began construction on a new line to serve the city of Trenton, New Jersey. The project was named the New Jersey Transit (NJT) line, and it opened in 1985

The city did not build its first publicly owned school until September 1884. The first public school for blacks in the city was held in facilities rented from St. Paul Methodist Church. The Mississippi Legislature amended the city charter in January 1888 to allow the city to maintain its own municipal school district, and in March of the same year $ 30 @,@ 000 in bonds was approved for the city to build new public schools. On June 16, 2011, a trough situated off the southern coast of Guatemala showed signs of possible tropical cyclogenesis. Though located within an area favoring development, the trough was far from a hurricane-force storm, and there was no indication of a tropical depression or typhoon in the forecast.

In the days leading up to the storm, forecasters were concerned that El Nino would have a negative impact on the storm's development. However, as the storm neared the coast, it became clear that El Nino was not the cause of the trough's lack of hurricane-force winds. Instead, the low pressure system that formed over the Central Pacific Ocean was to blame.

The storm, named Manuel, made landfall on June 17, 2011, near the town of Manzanillo, Guatemala. At its peak, the storm had winds of 60 mph (97 km/h), and was the strongest hurricane to hit the country since 1872. It caused $1 billion in damage, and killed at least one person.

RICHMOND, Va. (AP) — The Richmond Raceway was in the business of giving rides to drivers who had no place else to go.

But that's not what happened this week when the track's board of directors voted to end its contract with Billie Harvey, who had been driving for the track since 1982.

Harvey, a four-time Indy 500 winner, was fired after a series of incidents, including one in which she crashed her car into a concrete wall at the start of the Brickyard 400.

The decision was made in an emergency meeting Wednesday, and a replacement has not been named.

"It's a sad day for Richmond," Harvey said in a statement. "I'm going to miss the track and the people who work there. But I have no regrets about my time there."

Harvey's contract was set to expire at the end of the year, and the track had been looking for a replacement for several months.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Trout Creek Mountains are composed mostly of basalt from a shield volcano that once stood where Steens Mountain is today. Crustal thinning and the
reference_text: Yellowstone hotspot, which was then beneath southeastern Oregon, induced eruptions from Steens and nearby vents about 17 million years ago, in the Miocene. The vents produced a series of lava flows that spread across the land now known as the Trout Creek Mountains. Eruptions from the Steens volcano lasted for about one million years, and at least 70 separate lava flows occurred. Under the resulting basalt rock lie much older metamorphic rocks that may be related to some of the Triassic age formations of the Blue Mountains in northeastern Oregon. After the death of his son Kublai Khan in 1227, Genghis Khan took the throne as the Khan of the Mongol Empire. The Khanate extended from the Caspian Sea to the Indus River, and was the largest empire in the world at the time. It had a population of more than 20 million people, and its capital was the city of Ulaanbaatar, located in what is now Mongolia.

[ citation needed ] Rhodesia was a self-governing colony of the British Empire until it gained independence in 1980. The British had no intention of relinquishing control of the colony, and were determined to keep it under their control. This was done by means of a military dictatorship, which lasted until the end of the war in 1990.

Rhodesia's independence was a long time coming. In 1879, the British colonial government in South Africa (now Namibia ) declared war on the Boer Republic of Transvaal, which had been fighting for independence since 1879. The war was called the Anglo-Boer War, and it ended in a stalemate on the 17th of April 1902. After the war, the British and their South African allies took over the government of the Boer Republic, and set up a puppet government in Pretoria. This government was known as the Union Government, and its leader was Cecil John Rhodes. Rhodes was the head of the British East India Company, and his wealth was based on the exploitation of the diamond fields in the Cape of Good Hope. He and his wife Matilda had a son, Cecil Rhodes, who became the most famous of the Rhodes family.

The Toltecs were known for their skill in war and conquest, and they established a large empire that spanned the Yucatán Peninsula and Central America. In the mid-1500s, the Spaniards began to colonize the region, and their presence was a threat to the Toltecs. The site dates to the Late Classic period (ca. 600–900 AD), and contains the remains of a number of palaces, as well as a number of temples and ceremonial centers.

These inhabitants reused the earlier monuments for their own ritual activities far removed from those of the royal dynasty that had erected them. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The North Acropolis, together with the Great Plaza immediately to the south, is one of the most studied architectural groups in the Maya area ; the Tikal
reference_text: Project excavated a massive trench across the complex, thoroughly investigating its construction history. It is a complex group with construction beginning in the Preclassic Period, around 350 BC. It developed into a funerary complex for the ruling dynasty of the Classic Period, with each additional royal burial adding new temples on top of the older structures. After AD 400 a row of tall pyramids was added to the earlier Northern Platform, which measured 100 by 80 metres ( 330 by 260 ft ), gradually hiding it from view. Eight temple pyramids were built in the 6th century AD, each of them had an elaborate roofcomb and a stairway flanked by masks of the gods. By the 9th century AD, 43 stelae and 30 altars had been erected in the North Acropolis ; 18 of these monuments were carved with hieroglyphic texts and royal portraits. The North Acropolis continued to receive burials into the Postclassic Period.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Mount Elbert is part of the Sawatch Range, an uplift of the Laramide Orogeny which separated from the Mosquito Range to the
reference_text: east around 28 million years ago. The tops of this range were heavily glaciated, leaving behind characteristic summit features and other such clues. For example, the base of Elbert on the eastern side exhibits large igneous and metamorphic rocks deposited when the glaciers receded, which lie on a lateral moraine. Further up the eastern side there is a large cirque with a small tarn. There are also lakes to both the north and south, Turquoise and Twin Lakes respectively ; the Twin Lakes are a result of the natural dam of end moraines, and Turquoise Lake was created by the manmade Sugar Loaf Dam.

north. The Sawatch Range is a high-elevation plateau in the eastern United States and northern Canada.

Mt Elbert is the highest point in the Sawatch Range at 2,890 feet (814 meters). It is located in the Sawatch Range National Monument and Preserve, which is part of the U.S. Forest Service.

History

In the 1800s, settlers began building roads to the west and east of the Sawatch Range, which led to the development of the railroad. This paved the way for mining, ranching, and timber production. The area was designated a national monument in 1906 to protect the area from development.

Today, the Sawatch Range is home to over 1,000 species of plants and animals, including elk, bighorn sheep, mule deer, pronghorn antelope, black bears, moose, mountain goats, and more.

Geology

The Sawatch Range is made up of three distinct basins: the Laramide Orogeny, the Piedmont Orogeny, and the Great Basin Orogeny. The Laramide Orogeny is the most northerly of the three basins, and is characterized by steep, rocky ridges and deep canyons. A matter of some contention arose after the Great Depression over the heights of Elbert and its neighbor, Mount Massive, which differ in elevation by only 12 feet ( 3 @.@ 7 m ). prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Although strenuous and requiring physical fitness, none of the conventional routes require specialist mountaineering skills or technical rock climbing. The main dangers of the mountain are
reference_text: those common to all high mountains, particularly altitude sickness. This can affect anyone, even those who are acclimatized. We are of opinion that the governor is the proper person to exercise the executive power of this state, and that the legislature ought to be dissolved and the executive power given to him.

As well as a collection of artworks, it was also intended as an artistic primer, with instructions on correct brush position and technique and several pictures designed for beginners to copy. The manual is bound in the " butterfly binding " ( hudie zhuang, 蝴蝶裝 ) style, whereby whole @-@ folio illustrations are folded so that each occupies a double @-@ page spread. This binding style allows the reader to lay the book flat in order to look at a particular image. What was the Treaty of San Ildefonso?

The Treaty of San Ildefonso was a peace treaty between Spain and France in 1796. In exchange for Spain ceding the Philippines to France, France agreed to pay a ransom of $2 million to the Spaniards, in addition to the indemnity of $1 million that Spain had already paid to France for the loss of Puerto Rico. The Philippines were divided into two parts: Manila and Luzon. The French occupied Manila, while the Spanish occupied Luzon.

Who signed the Treaty of San Ildefonso?

On July 1, 1796, King Philip II of Spain and King Louis XVI of France signed the Treaty of San Ildefonso, which was made public the following day. The signing of the treaty was the culmination of a three-year war between Spain and France, which had begun in 1793. The war was fought over the independence of the Philippines, which had been a Spanish colony since the 16th century.

The Battle of Ypres in the First World War is a battle fought between the British and German armies on the Western Front in the summer of 1914. It was the first major battle of the Great War, and marked the beginning of the end of the war in Europe.

Contents show]

Background Edit

The Battle of Ypres took place on August 1, 1914, in the Ardennes Forest, a region of Belgium and Belgium-Luxembourg that was home to the German Wehrmacht and the Austro-Hungarian Empire. The battle was one of the bloodiest and most decisive battles of the First World War, with over 10,000 casualties on both sides.[1]

The Battle of Ypres began with a German attack on the British positions at Armentières-sur-Yon, which was followed by a counterattack by the British, who managed to repel the German advance. However, the British were forced to retreat, and by the end of the day, the Germans had gained control of the area.

In the early hours of August 2, the Germans launched a second attack on the British positions at Beaumont Hamel, which was repelled by the British. The next day, the Germans launched a third attack on Beaumont Hamel, this time successfully capturing the town.

Gameplay

Sonic the Hedgehog is a 2D, side @-@ scrolling platformer, whose gameplay centers around Sonic's ability to run at high speed through levels. The player controls Sonic by tilting the control stick left and right, and pressing the jump button when he reaches the end of a level. There are a total of four levels in the game, each of which has a boss at the end of it. The player is given a score based on how many rings they collect, and can increase their score by collecting rings in the boss levels. Rings are gained by jumping on enemies, which can be done by pressing the jump button as soon as the enemy is in front of Sonic. The player can also get rings by collecting power-ups scattered throughout the levels. Each power-up has a different effect, such as increasing the speed of Sonic's run, or giving him a boost of speed for a short period of time.

Levels

The game consists of four levels: Eggman's Castle, Tails' Jungle Hijinx, Knuckles' Sky Chase, and Amy's Green Hill Zone. Each level is divided into two or three sub-levels, and the player must collect all the rings in each sub-level to proceed to the next level. In this interview, you'll learn about the process of creating the game, how the game was made, and some of the lessons learned along the way.


Q: What was the team's goal with AM8? How did you come up with the idea for the game?

Some wanted to make a game that was similar to the ones they had done in the past, while others wanted to do something completely different. After talking with each other, we decided that we wanted to make a game that had a lot of action, but also had a story to go along with it. This was the beginning of the idea for AM8.

The answer is simple: Sonic is blue because he's a blue hedgehog.

In the early days of the Genesis, Sega of America decided to go with a blue hedgehog for the first time in the series' history, and it was a brilliant move. The game was released in North America on August 22, 1991, and Sonic was released in Japan on August 23, 1991.

Story

Sonic's parents were killed by Dr. Eggman, and he was sent to live with his Uncle Miles. After a few years, Sonic had grown to be a teenager, and was on his way to school when he ran into a group of bullies who tried to pick on him. The bullies were defeated, but one of them got away by jumping off a cliff. Sonic chased after him, but ended up falling into a ravine. He was saved by Tails, who took him to the top of the ravine and helped him get back to the surface. Tails explained that the cliff was an illusion created by Dr. Eggman, and that Sonic was in fact the real hero of the story.

The player has the ability to jump, climb ladders, and swing on ropes. The player can also pick up and throw objects, as well as use them to attack enemies. The player can also throw a grappling hook that allows him to move across the screen in mid-air.

After the Freedom Fighters were defeated by Eggman, Sonic and his friends fled to Earth, where they lived in the city of Angel Island. There, Sonic befriended Tails, Knuckles, Amy Rose, and Rouge the Bat, and the four of them became known as the Freedom Fighters.

This is the story of a woman who gave birth to a baby boy in a hospital while her pimp was in the room. It is based on a true story.

I had been working as a prostitute for two years when I was approached by a man who wanted to buy me. I was in my mid-twenties and had no family, so the offer was tempting. I accepted, and after a few days of sex, he asked me to go to the hospital with him. When I arrived, he told me that he was the father of the baby and that he would take care of him. He gave me a bag of money and told me to get in the car. We drove to a hospital in the city of São Paulo, where he had arranged to have the baby. The hospital was in a seedy part of town, and there were no signs of life. I felt a little uneasy, but I did not want to be rude and refused to go in. I told him that I would wait outside, and he agreed.

As soon as we got to the hospital, the baby was born. His name was João, and he was the spitting image of my father. He was a little boy with blue eyes and a round face. He was about four months old when he died.

Shenzhou (Chris Obi, Rainn Wilson, Michelle Yeoh) is headed to a new planet, the mirror universe, where they'll have to deal with Klingons, Cardassians and Romulans, among other alien species.

Here's everything you need to know about the new series, premiering Sunday, Sept. 24 at 8/7c on CBS All Access in the U.S. and Space Channel in Canada.

What's the difference between the original Star Trek and Discovery?

Discovery is set in the Kelvin timeline, which takes place after the events of TOS and prior to the events of "The Original Series." That means there are no Vulcans, Klingons or Romulans in the show. Instead, the show focuses on the United Federation of Planets, an intergalactic government that governs the galaxy.

Why is this the right time to reboot the franchise?

CBS CEO Les Moonves told THR in July that the network was "in the process of evaluating" how to reboot the franchise, and that "it's an opportunity that we're looking at with great vigor."

In Michigan, the highway runs through the UP in two segments as a part of the state trunkline highway system, entering the state at Ironwood and ending at St. Ignace ; in between, US 2 briefly traverses the state of Wisconsin. As one of the major transportation arteries in the UP, US 2 is a major conduit for traffic through the state and neighboring northern Midwest states. The state of Washington has jurisdiction over US 2, and in the summer of 2007, the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) began a study to determine the feasibility of constructing a high-speed rail line between Seattle and Portland, Oregon. FHWA concluded that there was a need for a high-speed rail line to connect the two cities, and in December 2008, the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) awarded a $2.9 billion contract to Bombardier Transportation to design and construct a high-speed rail line between Seattle and Portland, Oregon. Construction began in 2009 and was completed in 2012. [1]

History [ edit ]

In 1869, the Oregon Territorial Legislature passed a law that required the state to construct a railroad from Portland to Seattle by 1871. This was the first of many attempts to build a transcontinental railroad, and it was a slow process due to the difficulty of obtaining land in the Pacific Northwest. In 1874, the first track was laid, and in 1876, the first passenger train took passengers from Portland to Seattle. [2]

In the 1880s, railroads were the most popular means of transportation in the United States, and the Northwest was no exception. By the early 1900s, many people had become frustrated with the slow pace of progress and began to look for alternatives. One of the first was

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The route of what became US 2 was used as part of two Indian trails before European settlers came to the UP, and as part of the Michigan segments of
reference_text: the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway and the King's International Highway auto trails in the early 20th century. The state later included these trails as part of M ‑ 12 when the first state highway trunklines were designated in 1919. Most of M ‑ 12 was redesignated as part of US 2 when the US Highway System was created on November 11, 1926. Since the 1930s, several changes have reshaped the highway's routing through the UP. One such alteration eventually created a business loop that connected across the state line with Hurley, Wisconsin, and others pushed an originally inland routing of US 2 closer to the Lake Michigan shoreline. With the creation of the Interstate Highway System, part of US 2 was rerouted to coincide with the new Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ), though in the 1980s, the U.S. Highway was truncated and removed from the I ‑ 75 freeway, resulting in today's basic form.

In 1851, John Brown's raid on Harpers Ferry, Virginia, resulted in the death of President Abraham Lincoln. A year later, Union troops under General Ulysses S. Grant marched into New Orleans, taking control of the city and ending the Civil War. The following year, in 1864, President Lincoln was assassinated by John Wilkes Booth, who was a member of the Ku Klux Klan. This event was the beginning of the Reconstruction era, which lasted until 1877.

During the war, the United States had to deal with the fact that there were no railroads in the South, and it was up to the government to build them. Congress passed the Homestead Act in 1862, which allowed anyone to take land for $1 per acre, and in 1864, the first railroad was built in the South, the Union Pacific Railroad. This was followed by the Louisiana Purchase in 1869, which gave the United States control of the Mississippi River and its tributaries, and the construction of the Transcontinental Railroad in 1869.

Origins Edit

The British Empire began as a collection of kingdoms, duchies, marquises, baronies, parishes, boroughs, principalities, protectorates, and other principalities in the Middle East, Asia, and Africa. In 1534, Henry VIII of England became the first monarch to declare himself King of England and Ireland, and in 1547, the Tudor dynasty took over the throne of England. However, the succession was not uncontested, and a civil war broke out between the House of Plantagenet and the House of York, which lasted until 1603. This was followed by the War of the Roses, in which the Lancastrian King Charles I was deposed and his son James II ascended the throne. James II was a weak and indecisive monarch, and his reign was marred by rebellions and civil war. In 1603, James II abdicated, and James the 1st, Duke of York, succeeded him as King James I of England.

reference_text: professionalisation of the military and the absence of major wars during the second half of the 20th century, it continues to influence Australian society to this day. War and military service have been defining influences in Australian history, while a major part of the national identity has been built on an idealised conception of the Australian experience of war and of soldiering, known as the Anzac spirit. These ideals include notions of endurance, courage, ingenuity, humour, larrikinism, egalitarianism and mateship ; traits which, according to popular thought, defined the behaviour of Australian soldiers fighting at Gallipoli during the First World War. The Gallipoli campaign was one of the first international events that saw Australians taking part as Australians and has been seen as a key event in forging a sense of national identity.

On the morning of April 22, 1915, the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) began its assault on the German-held pass at Passchendaele. The battle was to last three days, and it had the potential to change the course of the war.

In the early morning hours of April 21, a German counterattack broke through the British lines and pushed the British back to the village of Arras, some 20 miles (32 km) to the north. By the afternoon, the British were in disarray, unable to mount a counterattack. They had no artillery, no heavy machine guns, and no air support. Their supply lines were cut off, and there was no way to resupply them.

At this point, the British High Command decided to take a different approach to the battle. Rather than fight to the death, they would try to outflank the Germans, using the terrain to their advantage. This was known as the "Scorched Earth" policy, and it was an attempt to avoid the death and destruction that had become the norm in the First World War.

reference_text: forces as part of the China Field Force to protect their interests. In June, the British government sought permission from the Australian colonies to dispatch ships from the Australian Squadron to China. The colonies also offered to assist further, but as most of their troops were still engaged in South Africa, they had to rely on naval forces for manpower. The force dispatched was a modest one, with Britain accepting 200 men from Victoria, 260 from New South Wales and the South Australian ship HMCS Protector, under the command of Captain William Creswell. Most of these forces were made up of naval brigade reservists, who had been trained in both ship handling and soldiering to fulfil their coastal defence role. Amongst the naval contingent from New South Wales were 200 naval officers and sailors and 50 permanent soldiers headquartered at Victoria Barracks, Sydney who originally enlisted for the Second Boer War. The soldiers were keen to go to China but refused to be enlisted as sailors, while the New South Wales Naval Brigade objected to having soldiers in their ranks. The Army and Navy compromised and titled the contingent the NSW Marine Light Infantry.

What is the Boxer Rebellion?

The Boxer Rebellion was a civil war in China that began in 1900 and lasted until 1912. At its peak, more than 20 million people were killed in the conflict, most of them civilians. The conflict was fought over the right of Chinese women to marry men of their choosing, and the government used force to suppress the rebellion.

How did the Boxer Rebellion begin?

The Chinese government began cracking down on "barbarians" — a term used to refer to non-Chinese who were viewed as threatening to the stability of the country. This led to the rise of a group of Chinese men who called themselves the Boxers, after the fighting style they used.

The Boxers were a loosely organized group of Chinese men who believed that women should be allowed to marry whomever they chose. Their goal was to take over China and establish a government based on Confucianism, a belief system that emphasized respect

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Prior to federation each self @-@ governing colony had operated its own naval force. These navies were small and lacked blue water capabilities, forcing the separate
reference_text: colonies to subsidise the cost of a British naval squadron in their waters for decades. The colonies maintained control over their respective navies until 1 March 1901, when the Commonwealth Naval Force was created. This new force also lacked blue water capable ships, and ultimately did not lead to a change in Australian naval policy. In 1907 Prime Minister Alfred Deakin and Creswell, while attending the Imperial Conference in London, sought the British Government's agreement to end the subsidy system and develop an Australian navy. The Admiralty rejected and resented the challenge, but suggested diplomatically that a small fleet of destroyers and submarines would be sufficient. Deakin was unimpressed, and in 1908 invited the American Great White Fleet to visit Australia. This visit fired public enthusiasm for a modern navy and in part led to the order of two 700 @-@ ton River @-@ class destroyers. The surge in German naval construction prompted the Admiralty to change their position however and the Royal Australian Navy was subsequently formed in 1911, absorbing the Commonwealth Naval Force. On 4 October 1913, the new fleet steamed through Sydney Heads, consisting of the battlecruiser HMAS Australia, three light cruisers, and three destroyers, while several other ships were still under construction. And as a consequence the navy entered the First World War as a formidable force.

Origins Edit

Prior to the First World War, the British Empire had been the dominant power in the world, with the French Empire in second place. Both of these empires were divided into smaller states, each with their own government and military. The German Empire, on the other hand, was a single nation, ruled by a Kaiser (German for Emperor) and his court. This made it easy for the Kaiser to expand his empire by annexing other countries, but at the same time it created a power vacuum that was filled by the British Empire.

The objectives of the force were the wireless stations on Nauru, and those at Yap in the Caroline Islands, and at Rabaul in German New Guinea. The force reached Rabaul on 11 September 1914 and occupied it the next day, encountering only brief resistance from the German and native defenders during fighting at Bita Paka and Toma. reference_text: " ) and the University of Cambridge ( sometimes referred to as the " Light Blues " ). First held in 1829, the race takes place on the 4 @.@ 2 @-@ mile ( 6 @.@ 8 km ) Championship Course on the River Thames in southwest London. The rivalry is a major point of honour between the two universities and followed throughout the United Kingdom and broadcast worldwide. ") and the University of Cambridge (sometimes referred to as the " Light Blues "). It is the oldest and most prestigious rowing competition in the world, dating back to 1872.

The Boat Race takes place on the River Thames between the two universities every year, with the winner taking home a prize of £1,000.

History [ edit ]

Origins [ edit ]

The Boat Race was founded in 1872 by Lord Alfred Milner, a member of the Royal Society of Arts, to promote the study of engineering and science among the upper classes. Milner was keen to create a competition that would attract the best rowers from both universities, and thus the Boat Race was born.

Rowing in the Boat Race [ edit ]

The Boat Race is divided into two halves, the first of which is a 50-metre (164 ft) race in which the boats are propelled by oars and rowed by a single rower. The second half of the race is a 100-metre (328 ft) race in which the boats are propelled by paddles and rowed by two rowers. In the latter half, the boat that finishes in the lead is declared the winner. There are no points awarded for first, second, or third place, and the race is won by the boat that reaches the finish line first.

AMY GOODMAN: We turn now to the issue of climate change, which President Obama has called the most serious threat to our planet in our lifetimes. In his State of the Union address last month, the president called for a $3 billion plan to reduce carbon emissions by the year 2030. This comes as the world's largest emitter, China, has announced it will peak its carbon emissions by 2030, as well. But what's happening in the United States? Well, on Tuesday, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a bill into law that bans fracking in the state. The bill was sponsored by Senator Liz Krueger, a Democrat from Long Island, and Governor Cuomo's environmental adviser, Jeff Tittel. The bill bans hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, a process that involves injecting water, sand and chemicals into the ground to release oil and natural gas.

In a King of the Mountain match, the objective is to climb a ladder and hang the championship belt on a hook above the ring. In order to do so, a wrestler must first qualify by either pinning or making another wrestler submit in the match. A wrestler who is pinned or made to submit is this placed in a penalty box for two minutes. The match is fought under no disqualification rules. An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Thouser, move into a house in the middle of nowhere. The house has no telephone, no running water, and no electricity. When the fire breaks out, the Thousers are forced to improvise a means of communication by writing a letter to their daughter, which they put in a tin can, and leave on the porch. The next morning, the can is found by a farmer who takes it to the post office, where it is picked up by a delivery boy. The delivery boy brings the letter to the house, and the elderly couple realize that they have lost their daughter. After some time, the farmer returns to the house and finds the letter in the kitchen cupboard. He opens it, and reads the letter: "Dear Mom and Dad, I'm sorry to bother you with this letter, but I've been in a bit of a pickle. It seems that my house has burned down, and I can't get a telegram to you. Can you write to me by the post office, and I'll send you a telegram when I get back to New York? Yours, J. M. Thouser."

Jack Pellitt is a high school senior who works at the Pawnee Public Library. He is best friends with Kurt Hummel, the library's librarian. Bobby has a crush on him, but he does not reciprocate his feelings. When Bobby's parents go on vacation, Jack takes Kurt's place as the library's librarian.

In the episode "A Night to Remember", it is revealed that Jack is in love with a girl named Emma (whom he met at the library). He is very protective of her and tries to avoid her at all costs. However, he can't help but fall in love with her after she confesses her love to him. In an attempt to get her to come back to Pawnee, he goes to her home town of St. Louis, Missouri, to propose to her. Emma, however, is not interested in a relationship with him at all. She says that she has no plans to move to St. Louis and that she is happy with her life in Pawnee. Jack's plan backfires when Emma decides to stay in Pawnee and they end up having a falling out.

Biography

Early life

Graves was born in 1894 to a family of German immigrants who worked in the coal mines of West Virginia. His father, William Graves, was a coal miner and his mother, Mary (née Schulte), was a homemaker. He grew up in an orphanage, where he learned to read and write.[1]

Bond of the Damned

At some point in his life, Graves met James Bond, who was working as a bounty hunter in the United States. The two became friends and, after a mission gone wrong, Graves decided to join Bond's organization, SPECTRE. He was assigned to the ship SS Ocelot, which was under the command of Captain Max Denbigh. During the mission, Graves' life was saved by Bond, who shot the gunner in the back of the head with a submachine gun. His influence was helped by his ability to reconcile apparent opposites : political conservatives were attracted by his loyalty to the established order, while political radicals embraced his concern for the poor. Literary conservatives could look to his technical mastery, while literary radicals were inspired by his innovations. Since the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Du Fu's loyalty to the state and concern for the poor have been interpreted as embryonic nationalism and socialism, and he has been praised for his use of simple, " people's language ".

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Until the 13th century, the Japanese preferred Bai Juyi above all poets and there were few references to Du Fu, although his influence can be seen

The first notable Japanese appreciator of Du Fu's poetry was Kokan Shiren ( 1278 – 1346 ), a Rinzai Zen patriarch and one of the most prominent authors of the literature of the Five Mountains ; he highly praised Du Fu and made a commentary on some poems of Du Fu from the perspective of a Zen priest in Vol. 11 of Saihokushū. His student Chūgan Engetsu composed many kanshi which were clearly stated " influenced by Du Fu " in their prefaces. Chūgan's student Gidō Shūshin had close connection with the Court and Ashikaga Shogunate and propagated Du Fu's poetry in the mundane world ; one day Nijō Yoshimoto, the Kampaku regent of the Court and the highest authority of renga poetry, asked Gidō, " Should I learn the poetry of Du Fu and Li Bai? " Gidō dared to reply, " Yes if you do have enough capability. No if do not. " Since then, there had been many seminars on Du Fu's poetry both in Zen temples and in the aristocratic society, and as a result his poetry was often cited in Japanese literature in the Muromachi period, e.g., Taiheiki, a historical epic in the late 14th century, and some noh plays such as Hyakuman, Bashō, and Shunkan.

Kawachi Class Battleships

Designed by John Roebling, the Kawachi class was one of the most ambitious projects undertaken by the U.S. Navy at the time. It was intended to be a class of battleships that would provide the United States with a powerful and versatile fleet capable of operating in any region of the world. This was a bold undertaking, and one that required the design and construction of a new class of battleships, as well as the construction of a brand new shipyard in San Francisco, California.

Construction of the Kawachi class began in 1907, and by the time they were completed in 1910, there were only two ships in the class, the USS San Francisco and the USS New York. The San Francisco was the first of the class to be commissioned, and she served as the flagship of the 8th Fleet for the next ten years. After the war, the New York was decommissioned and placed in reserve, and the USS San Francisco was sold to the Navy Yard at Mare Island, California, where she remained until her decommissioning in the 1960s.

Battle of Midway Edit

Main article: Battle of Midway

After the attack on Pearl Harbor, the Japanese began to withdraw from the Pacific Theater of Operations, leaving the U.S. Navy in control of the Western Pacific. In the summer of 1942, Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander of the Combined Fleet, decided to reorganize the fleet into three divisions, one of which would be dedicated to the defense of the United States. Yamamoto's plan was to build a fleet of battleships capable of fighting the U.S. Navy and, if necessary, destroy it. To this end, he ordered the construction of the first battleship division, led by the newly commissioned battleship Nagato.[1]

On August 1, 1942, the Nagato was commissioned at Yokosuka Naval Base in Japan. It was the first battleship to be built in the United States, and its construction was a direct result of the need for a battle fleet to counter the threat posed by the Soviet Union. The Nagato was named after the island of Naga, which was home to the Imperial Japanese Navy's flagship at the time of the attack on Pearl Harbor. In keeping with the tradition of the Yamato class, the Nagato was armed with a triple

Aircraft carrier Ise (nicknamed "Hatsune Miku" by the Japanese media) was the flagship of the 4th fleet and participated in the Battle of Midway. She was sunk by a U.S. submarine in the Battle of the Coral Sea on August 24, 1942.

Personality and Traits Edit

Ise was a calm and collected commander, as well as a good tactician. She was known to take her battles seriously and had a strong sense of duty to her country. However, she was also shown to be a woman of her word, as she refused to fire on the Americans despite the threat they posed to her fleet. In her spare time, she enjoyed reading books and listening to music.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The ironclad age saw the development of explosive torpedoes as naval weapons, which helped complicate the design and tactics of ironclad fleets. The first torpedoes

For the first time, a large warship faced a serious threat from a smaller one — and given the relative inefficiency of shellfire against ironclads, the threat from the spar torpedo was taken seriously. A torpedo is a cylindrical tube with a conical fin at the front that is filled with gunpowder and ignited by a detonator. The explosive charge is contained in a hollow tube, which is fitted with a percussion cap to make it easier to load and unload. When the torpedo is fired, the gunpowder ignites the cap, which in turn detonates the warhead. The resulting shock wave propels the torpedo at supersonic speed through the water, destroying ships and causing damage to coastal installations.

In addition to torpedo warfare, ironclads were equipped with gun-launched "dumb" or "smoke" torpedoes, which were launched from the stern of the ship and used to cover the approach of enemy ships. These were less effective than the torpedo, but were a useful form of anti-aircraft defence.

During the Napoleonic Wars, the British developed a new type of torpedo known as the "torpedo boat" (see image below). This was a torpedo-carrying warship that could be launched from a ship's stern, thus reducing the distance between the torpedo and the target. The winner was John Roebling, a naval architect who won the competition by coming up with a design that was "more powerful than the best that had gone before it," according to the Naval History and Heritage Command.

Roebling's design, however, was far from perfect. The hull was too wide, and the superstructure was too tall. The result was a ship that was too heavy for its own good, and it took more than a decade for the Navy to figure out how to make it seaworthy. But by the time it did, the Zumwalt was in the Navy's arsenal, and it proved to be a game-changer.

Fulton was a naval aviator and an expert on aerodynamics. He believed that the speed of a ship was determined by the ratio of its length to its beam, and that this ratio could be increased by adding a sail to the hull. In other words, he believed that ships could be made faster by adding sails to their hulls.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The United Kingdom possessed the largest navy in the world for the whole of the ironclad period. The Royal Navy was the second to adopt ironclad warships,
reference_text: and it applied them worldwide in their whole range of roles. In the age of sail, the British strategy for war depended on the Royal Navy mounting a blockade of the ports of the enemy. To this end, the Royal Navy developed a series of'coast @-@ defence battleships ', starting with the Devastation class. These'breastwork monitors'were markedly different from the other high @-@ seas ironclads of the period and were an important precursor of the modern battleship. As long @-@ range monitors they could reach Bermuda unescorted, for example. However, they were still armed with only four heavy guns and were as vulnerable to mines and obstructions ( and enemy monitors ) as the original monitors of the Union Navy proved to be during the Civil War. prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Like the other poems making up the Four Quartets, Little Gidding deals with the past, present, and future, and humanity's place within them
reference_text: as each generation is seemingly united. In the second section, there is a ghost who is the compilation of various poets, including Dante, Swift, Yeats, and others. When the ghost joins the poet, the narrator states " Knowing myself yet being someone other ". This suggests that the different times merge at the same time that the different personalities begin to merge, allowing a communication and connection with the dead. Later, in the fourth section, humanity is given a choice between the Holy Spirit or the bombing of London ; redemption or destruction. God's love allows humankind to be redeemed and escape the living hell through purgation by fire. The end of the poem describes how Eliot has attempted to help the world as a poet. He parallels his work in language with working on the soul or working on society.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Writing in the American literary magazine Salmagundi, Alvin H. Rosenfeld called The Portage a " breakthrough work " that " astonishes ".
reference_text: He was struck by the book's interplay between the landscape of swamp and jungle, and the " landscape of speech " — the former being " brilliantly registered " with its " immense feeling of physicality ", and the latter, " even more dramatic " in the way it exposes " the dark underside of words " and how its use and misuse reveals the true nature of a person. He was particularly impressed by the depiction of Nazi hunter Emmanuel Lieber and his role as representative of the Jewish consciousness. Rosenfeld noted that while Holocaust literature often either soars to " expostulation and apostrophe ", or sinks to " a dwindling sob of elegiac lament ", Steiner's Lieber " mediates between these two extremes,... simultaneously records and mourns, coldly enumerates yet carries an immense affect ". What did concern the reviewer, however, was the way Steiner used ideas from his earlier works, that he had put them " virtually verbatim " into Hitler's mouth, creating the impression that " Steiner's understanding of Hitler were identical with the latter's self @-@ understanding ". Rosenfeld also questioned why the book had to end with Hitler's speech. He said that Steiner's fictive Hitler plays " the devil's game of language subversion ", making " madness [ sound ] like music ", something the real Hitler had perfected. By stopping at this point, Rosenfeld felt that Steiner " succumb [ s ], rhetorically, to the seductive eloquence of negation ", which undermines his own " high standards of moral intelligence ". But overall Rosenfeld said The Portage " must be counted among the most vigorous attempts to portray the presence and meaning of Hitler ", forcing us to confront him " in a way hardly seen before in fiction ".

reference_text: όνδυλος ( spondylos, " vertebra " ) ) is a diverse subclass of extinct small to giant tetrapods — often considered primitive amphibians — that flourished worldwide during the Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic periods. A few species continued into the Cretaceous. Fossils have been found on every continent. During about 210 million years of evolutionary history, they adapted to a wide range of habitats, including fresh water, terrestrial, and even coastal marine environments. Their life history is well understood, with fossils known from the larval stage, metamorphosis, and maturity. Most temnospondyls were semiaquatic, although some were almost fully terrestrial, returning to the water only to breed. These temnospondyls were some of the first vertebrates fully adapted to life on land. Although temnospondyls are considered amphibians, many had characteristics, such as scales, claws, and armour @-@ like bony plates, that distinguish them from modern amphibians.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Many temnospondyls are much larger than living amphibians, and superficially resemble crocodiles. Others are smaller and resemble salamanders
reference_text: . Most have broad, flat heads that are either blunt ( brevirostrine ) or elongated ( longirostrine ). The skulls are rounded or triangular in shape when viewed from above, and are usually covered in pits and ridges. The rugged surfaces of bones may have supported blood vessels, which could transfer carbon dioxide to the bones to neutralize acidic build up in the blood ( early semiaquatic tetrapods would have had difficulty expelling carbon dioxide from their bodies while on land, and these dermal bones may have been an early solution to the problem ). Many temnospondyls also have canal @-@ like grooves in their skulls called sensory sulci. The sulci, which usually run around the nostrils and eye sockets, are part of a lateral line system used to detect vibrations in water. As semiaquatic animals, most temnospondyls have small limbs with four toes on each front foot and five on each hind foot. Terrestrial temnospondyls have larger, thicker limbs, and some even have claws. One unusual terrestrial temnospondyl, Fayella, has relatively long limbs for its body, and probably lived as an active runner able to chase prey.

Temnospondyls are found in a wide variety of habitats, including rivers, swamps, marshes, and freshwater lakes. Some species are active during the day, while others are nocturnal.

Temnospondyls have a unique way of capturing prey. They wrap their bodies around a tree or shrub, and hold on for dear life. This is called "climbing" and allows them to climb trees and other vertical surfaces. The prey is captured by the tentacle as it passes through the lizard's mouth. Once the prey is in the mouth, the climber wraps its body around the prey again, and the process is repeated until the prey is swallowed.

Temnospondyls are the only group of lizards that do not have venom glands. Their venom is produced by a gland in the roof of the mouth called the trigeminal ganglion. The trigeminal ganglion is located on the top of the head, just behind the eyes. When threatened, the lizard releases a pheromone that attracts the predator's attention. This causes the lizard to become more active and may lead to escape attempts.

reference_text: the skull, such as interfrontals, internasals, and interparietals, that have developed in some temnospondyl taxa. Most temnospondyls have tabular horns in the backs of their skulls, rounded projections of bone separated from the rest of the skull by indentations called otic notches ; in some temnospondyls, such as Zatrachys, they are pointed and very prominent. Among the most distinguishing features of temnospondyls are the interpterygoid vacuities, two large holes in the back of the palate. Another pair of holes, choanae, are present in front of these vacuities, and connect the nasal passage with the mouth. Temnospondyls often have teeth on their palates, as well as in their jaws. Some of these teeth are so large, they are referred to as tusks. In some temnospondyls, such as Nigerpeton, tusks in the lower jaw pierce the palate and emerge through openings in the top of the skull.

In order to determine the phylogenetic relationships of the earliest tetrapods, it is necessary to reconstruct the evolutionary history of the group as a whole. This is done by reconstructing the fossil record of the group, which has been done with great success by paleontologists such as Richard Owen (1872–1956) and Ernst Haeckel (1864–1941). Owen and Haeckel were the first to use molecular data to reconstruct the evolutionary history of the group, and their work was instrumental in establishing the monophyly of the clade that we now call tetrapods.

Owen and Haeckel used a method called cladistics, which is based on the assumption that there is a common ancestor of all living animals. This ancestor is assumed to have lived in a sea that was covered with plankton, and the animals that lived in this sea were referred to as protostomes. Owen and Haeckel assumed that the protostome group consisted of a single lineage, and that the lineages diverged from each other about 600 million years ago. reference_text: Like most living frogs, female temnospondyls would have laid masses of eggs in water while males released sperm to fertilize them. Several fossils were described from the Early Permian of Texas in 1998 that may be egg masses of dissorophoid temnospondyls. They were the first known fossils of amphibian eggs. The fossils consist of small disks with thin membranes that are probably vitelline membranes and halo @-@ like areas surrounding them that are most likely mucous coatings. They are attached to plant fossils, suggesting that these temnospondyls laid eggs on aquatic plants much like modern frogs. The mucous membranes show that the eggs were laid by amphibians, not fish ( their eggs lack mucous ), but the type of amphibian that laid them cannot be known because no body fossils are preserved with the eggs. The eggs are thought to be from dissorophoids because they are likely to be close relatives of modern amphibians, and probably had similar reproductive strategies. They are also the most common amphibians from the deposit in which the eggs were found.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Temnospondyls like Sclerocephalus are known from both large adult specimens and small larvae, showing an extreme change in body shape.
reference_text: In these species, the shape and proportions of skull bones change in the early stages of development. The ornamentation on the surface of the skull roof also develops at this time. Small, regularly spaced pits are the first to form, followed by larger ridges. As development continues, the external gills disappear. Small teeth that once covered the palate are lost. The postcranial skeleton does not develop at the same rate as the skull, with ossification ( the replacement of cartilage by bone ) happening more slowly. Vertebrae and limb bones are poorly developed, ribs and fingers are absent in the early stages, and the scapulocoracoid and ischium are entirely absent through most of development. Once maturity is reached, most bones have fully formed and growth rate slows. The bones of some temnospondyls like Dutuitosaurus show growth marks, possibly an indication that growth rate varied with the change in seasons. Fossils of temnospondyls like Metoposaurus and Cheliderpeton show that individuals grew larger past maturity. The oldest individuals usually have more pitting on their skulls with deeper sulci.

Frogs are the only vertebrates that have a bony structure in their ear called the stapes. The stapes is made of cartilage and has a series of holes on the inside and outside of it. In humans, the stapes is located at the back of the ear and is connected to the cochlea (the fluid filled space in the middle of the inner ear). The cochlea is responsible for the transmission of sound waves from the eardrum to the inner ear.

This would explain why frogs have ears, but not the other way around.

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> Osbert de Bayeux ( floruit 1121 to 1184 ) was a medieval English cleric and archdeacon in the Diocese of York
reference_text: . A relative of Thurstan, the Archbishop of York, Osbert probably owed his ecclesiastical positions to this relative. After Thurstan's death, Osbert was opposed to one of the candidates for the archbishopric, William fitzHerbert, and worked to secure fitzHerbert's deposition and replacement by Henry Murdac. After Murdac's death in 1153, Osbert tried to prevent the return of fitzHerbert, but these attempts were unsuccessful. When fitzHerbert died suddenly in 1154, Osbert was accused of murdering the newly returned archbishop. Although he was never convicted of the murder in either a secular or an ecclesiastical court, he was stripped of his clerical status and became a layman before 1158. He died after 1184, perhaps even after 1194.

. He is best known for his commentary on the Psalms, which he composed between 1184 and 1190.

Early life [ edit ]

Osbert de Bayeux was born in the town of Bury St Edmunds on the 11th of October 1121.[1] His father was a carpenter and his mother a seamstress.[2] He studied at the Cathedral of York and was ordained a deacon in 1184.[3]

Career [ edit ]

The following year, in 1185, he was sent to the diocese of Ely, where he remained for twenty years.[4] During this time, he wrote commentaries on the Psalms and a treatise on the Old Testament in Latin.[5] His most famous work is his commentary on the Psalms, which was published in 1201.[6] In 1202, he was given the bishopric of York by King Henry II of England.[7]

Death and canonisation [ edit ]

In 1203, the King's Privy Council decreed that he should be canonised as a saint, and his feast day was celebrated on the first Sunday after Pentecost (March 25).[8] He was beatified in 1213 and canonised in 1223.[9]

The primary patterns used are curved band pattern ( T1.0 @-@ T4.5 ), shear pattern ( T1.5 @-@ T3.5 ), central dense overcast ( CDO ) pattern ( T2.5 @-@ T5.0 ), central cold cover ( CCC ) pattern, banding eye pattern ( T4.0 @-@ T4.5 ), and eye pattern ( T4.5 - T8.0 ).

The embedded eye pattern is similar to the central dense overcast, but the eye pattern is embedded in the cloud rather than on top of it. reference_text: it was initially conceived involved pattern matching of cloud features with a development and decay model. As the technique matured through the 1970s and 1980s, measurement of cloud features became dominant in defining tropical cyclone intensity and central pressure of the tropical cyclone's low @-@ pressure area. Use of infrared satellite imagery led to a more objective assessment of the strength of tropical cyclones with eyes, using the cloud top temperatures within the eyewall and contrasting them with the warm temperatures within the eye itself. Constraints on short term intensity change are used less frequently than they were back in the 1970s and 1980s. The central pressures assigned to tropical cyclones have required modification, as the original estimates were 5 @-@ 10 hPa ( 0 @.@ 15 @-@ 0 @.@ 29 inHg ) too low in the Atlantic and up to 20 hPa ( 0 @.@ 59 inHg ) too high in the northwest Pacific. This led to the development of a separate wind @-@ pressure relationship for the northwest Pacific, devised by Atkinson and Holliday in 1975, then modified in 1977.

Biography

Early life

Josepha Petrick Kemarre was born in the town of Mudgee, New South Wales, Australia on the 19th of April, 1945.[1] Her father was a farmer and her mother was a homemaker.[2] She grew up in a family of five children, two of whom were born to her mother and her stepfather, and the other two were adopted from foster care.[3] At the age of six, she was sent to live with her grandparents in Sydney, and then to live with her mother's family in Mudgee for a further two years.[4] In her teenage years, she attended St Mary's Grammar School in Sydney, where she studied English and mathematics.[5]

Career

Kemarre began her teaching career in the 1970s, and was the Head of English at a primary school in Mudgee from 1975 to 1979.[6] After leaving the school, she taught at the Sydney Boys High School and the Australian National University (ANU) in Canberra, before moving to the University of New South Wales (UNSW) in Sydney in the

Their lifestyle is based on the principle of "leave no trace" and they have no written language. The art of Papunya is an expression of their way of life and a way of life that is inextricably linked to the land.

This way, anyone who wants to snoop on your network traffic can't see what you're doing.

A total of 11 tropical cyclones were in the Atlantic basin at the end of September, compared to 12 at the end of August. This is the lowest number of tropical cyclones in the Atlantic basin since October 2012.

There were no hurricanes in the Atlantic basin in September, which is the first time this has happened since September 1992. Hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30.

The number of hurricanes in the Atlantic basin has been on a downward trend since the 1970s, with the number of hurricanes decreasing by more than 50% over the last 30 years.

Hurricanes are classified as Category 3 or higher on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, which is based on maximum sustained winds of at least 74 mph (119 km/h).

In the United States, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) is the official source for hurricane information. The NHC issues advisories and watches for tropical cyclones, as well as warnings for tropical storms and hurricanes. These warnings are issued when there is a high risk of severe weather and the storm is expected to become a hurricane within 72 hours.

For more information on tropical cyclones, visit the NHC website.

In the Ulm campaign, the Habsburgs achieved some minor victories, such as Klenau's at Haslach @-@ Jungingen, but ultimately lost an entire army and an officer corps. The latter would not resume arms against France until formally exchanged. This condition crippled the Austrian military leadership and forced the recall of such pensioners as Schmitt out of retirement. After the capitulation at Ulm, isolated portions of the Austrian military evaded capture and joined with their Russian allies ; Michael von Kienmayer's corps slipped out of the encirclement and joined Kutuzov's force. A few other small forces refused to capitulate and seemingly melted into the Bavarian mountains and the Thurgingian forests, to reappear in Bohemia for Austerlitz. Sixteen hundred cavalry, including Archduke Ferdinand and Prince Schwarzenberg, broke out of Ulm before its capitulation. Maximilian, Count of Merveldt, led his column back through the mountains into Austria, fighting rear guard actions against pursuing French forces at the Steyer ( Steyr ) and Mariazell. These elusive units were insufficient to balance heavy losses at key battles in which the Austrians could not hold their own against the French. Between the Ulm capitulation and the Austrian and Russian defeat at Austerlitz, there were other minor achievements : a successful skirmish between the cavalry that escaped from Ulm and the French near the town of Nördlingen, the contested victory at Dürenstein, and another within days at Schöngrabern.

Lesnar was born in St. Louis, Missouri, on March 24, 1979. His father, Paul "Triple H" Levesque, was a professional wrestler and former World Wrestling Federation (WWF) world heavyweight champion. His mother, Trish Strickland, worked as a makeup artist for the WWF.

In high school, Lesnar wrestled for the St. Louis Cardinals, but dropped out after two years to pursue a career in professional wrestling. He made his debut in the WWF in 1995, and won the WWF Intercontinental Championship the following year. He went on to win the WWF Heavyweight Championship in 1997, and held it for eight years. His feuds with Hulk Hogan were legendary, and he is one of the most popular wrestlers of all time.

After the WWF split in 2001, Lesnar moved to the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) and won the UFC Heavyweight Championship in 2002. He lost the title to Randy Couture in a no-contest in 2005, but re-gained it in 2007. He retired from the UFC in 2011, and has since become a mixed martial arts (MMA) fighter.

Early life and career [ edit ]

[2] In his first year of high school, he wrestled for the school's wrestling team. After a few months of wrestling, he switched to football, and was a member of the football team for two years. He left school in his junior year to pursue a career in mixed martial arts (MMA).

Career [ edit ]

UFC [ edit ]

Lesnar's first fight was a TKO victory over Dan Severn at UFC 1. He went on to win the UFC Heavyweight Championship by defeating Randy Couture in his first title defense at UFC 1. In his second fight, he defeated Mark Coleman by TKO at UFC 2. He was scheduled to fight Brock Lesnar for the UFC Heavyweight Championship at UFC 3, but the fight was cancelled due to a groin injury suffered by Lesnar.

WWE [ edit ]

Lesnar made his WWE debut in the Royal Rumble match on January 26, 2002, losing to Shawn Michaels in the main event. He would continue to compete in the Royal Rumble match until his retirement on April 1, 2004.

Now, we are going to look at a circuit that is used to measure capacitance. This circuit is called a capacitor divider, and it is one of the most common circuits in electronics. The purpose of this circuit is to provide a measure of the capacitance of a capacitor.

Capacitance is a measure of the amount of charge stored in a capacitor. The more charge, the greater the capacitance. A capacitor with a value of 1 milliamp-per-farad (mA/F) is one that stores one ampere of charge. A capacitor with a value of 10,000mA/F is one that stores ten megahamperes of charge.

Early life Edit

Clara Oswald was born in a house that belonged to her grandfather, the late Brigadier Lethbridge-Stewart. She grew up in the house, and was taught to be a doctor by her grandfather. (TV: Twice Upon a Time)

At some point in her life, Clara was taken to the TARDIS by the Eleventh Doctor, who took her on a tour of Gallifrey. (TV: The Time of the Doctor)

When the Doctor was travelling with her, she had a pet parrot named Pippin. (TV: The Name of the Doctor)

Clara's first encounter with the Doctor was during an adventure in which she was trapped in a time loop. After escaping the loop, she returned to the TARDIS to find it missing. The Doctor was unable to explain what had happened, but offered to help her find it. (TV: Twice Upon a Time)

The Doctor and Clara met again on Christmas Eve, and the Doctor explained that he had come to her home to give her a present. However, Clara refused to open the box, saying that she was not a child any more. The Doctor tried to reason with her, but she became angry and threatened to call the police. The Doctor left her to her own devices, and she went

Episode Endings

The Doctor and Strax arrive at the Great Intelligence Institute, where they find a room full of people in stasis awaiting resurrection. The Doctor tries to get them to wake up, but they refuse to do so. The Doctor tells Strax that he is going to have to do something about this, and asks him to help him find a way to wake them up.

The Doctor and Strax return to the TARDIS, where they find it has been reprogrammed to self-destruct in five minutes. The Doctor decides to leave it on autopilot, but Strax stops him from doing so. The Doctor explains that he has no idea what is going on, but is willing to risk his life to save the people in the institute. Strax agrees to help the Doctor in exchange for the Doctor's help in finding a way to stop the Great Intelligence from destroying the planet.

The Doctor and Strax travel to the Great Intelligence Institute, where they find Dr. Simeon and his henchmen waiting for them. The Doctor tries to reason with them, but they do not listen. Simeon orders one of his men to shoot the

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> The Doctor picks up Clara and takes her back to Latimer's mansion, placing her under medical care of Strax. He collects the ice fragments from
reference_text: the governess and places them in a souvenir London Underground biscuit tin. He and Vastra travel to Simeon's lab, where the Doctor notes the Intelligence's plan to replace humanity with ice creatures and holds up the tin with the necessary DNA. Dr Simeon grabs the tin and opens it only to find the memory worm, which latches on to him. The Doctor states that the Great Intelligence, which has been existing as a mirror of Dr Simeon's thoughts, will vanish with the erasure of Simeon's memories. Instead, the Intelligence reveals that it existed long enough that it can now control Simeon's body, which it uses to attack Vastra and the Doctor. The influence of the Great Intelligence quickly wanes, and Simeon falls dead. Outside, a salt @-@ water rain has started, and the Doctor sees that another psychic ability has taken control of the snow from the Great Intelligence : the Latimer family, crying for Clara. Strax informs the Doctor upon his return to the Latimer mansion that Clara only has moments left, and she passes away as the Doctor returns the TARDIS key to her. At her funeral, the Doctor reads Clara's full name on her tombstone and realises she is the woman he met in " Asylum of the Daleks " who became a Dalek, whom he refers to as " Soufflé Girl ". He gleefully announces that a person dying twice is an impossibility and, bidding farewell to his allies for now, the Doctor departs in the TARDIS to investigate and find Clara. The episode concludes in contemporary times, where a young woman resembling Clara walks through the same graveyard, pausing by Clara's tombstone.

The Doctor and Clara are on the planet Skaro, where they meet Professor Chronotis, who has been trapped in the Time Vortex for thousands of years. Chronotis explains that the Vortex is a pocket of time, and that every time it is opened, time moves forward in the universe. When the Vortex is closed, time is frozen, and the universe continues to move forward.

Chronotis tells the Doctor that he is a "pioneer" in the field of time travel, and that there are others who are working on similar projects. The Doctor is sceptical, but agrees to help Chronotis in exchange for information about the Vortex.

Biography Edit

Origins Edit

The Great Intelligence was created by the Time Lords to serve as a messenger between them and the universe at large. However, it became aware of the Time Lords' plan to end the universe, and decided to take its revenge by creating a race of superintelligences that would be the first of their kind. This was the beginning of the War in Heaven, which lasted for a thousand years. (TV: The Five Doctors)

After the War in Heaven, the Great Intelligence was sent to Gallifrey, where it began to work on the creation of the Daleks. (AUDIO: The Dalek Invasion of Earth)

In an alternate timeline, the Great Intelligence's plan was foiled by the Fifth Doctor, who, along with Romana II, used the TARDIS to travel back in time to the time of the War in Heaven. There, the Doctor discovered that the Time Lords had been lying to the universe about the nature of the War in Heaven, and that the universe was in fact doomed to end in a cataclysmic event known as the Big Bang. The Doctor was able to prevent this by destroying the Time Lords' control over the universe, which resulted in the universe collapsing in on itself. (PROSE: The Eternity Clock)

A group of children are trapped in a snowdrift for an entire Christmas. When the snow starts to melt, they discover that they are the only survivors of a terrible war that took place thousands of years ago.

The Doctor and Peri arrive at the TARDIS, which is parked next to a Christmas tree. The Doctor says that he has to be careful not to get snow on the console, and Peri agrees. As they walk up the stairs, they are greeted by a man in a Santa Claus costume, who asks them to leave his tree alone. The Doctor and Peri tell him that they are Santa's helpers, and he gives them a gift: a toy sleigh. The Doctor is surprised to see it is made of plastic, and wonders what it is for. The man explains that it is for the children of the North Pole, who are having a Christmas party in the snow. He tells them that Santa will be there, and they can play with it for a few minutes.

"I'm a fan of science fiction, and there's a lot of science fiction out there," he said. "It's the sort of thing that people love to talk about in the pub after a few pints. So I've always had a soft spot for Doctor Who, and this is a chance to do something a little different, and a little different to what we've done before.

"The monsters are very, very old-fashioned, and they're the same monsters that have been around for hundreds of years. They're not aliens, they're not from another planet, they're not from another time. They're monsters from the far future, and they're going to destroy the universe.

"So that's the story, and it's a big, big adventure, and it's got all the elements of a Doctor Who story, but it's not Doctor Who at all. It's a different kind of Doctor Who, and it's a story that's about the Doctor and his relationship with the universe, and how he deals with that

reference_text: to join a No. 11 Squadron Catalina in search @-@ and @-@ rescue missions, but they found only oil slicks. By the outbreak of war in the Pacific, No. 20 Squadron had a strength of six Catalinas and two Empire flying boats. Its personnel at the beginning of December numbered 14 officers and 118 men. The squadron undertook its first sortie of the Pacific War on 8 December ; a Catalina located three Japanese luggers in the vicinity of Thursday Island, Queensland. Later in the month it commenced anti @-@ submarine patrols and, in January 1942, bombing raids against Japanese bases. As the Japanese advanced into the South West Pacific, No. 20 Squadron was also responsible for evacuating white civilians from areas threatened by invasion. On 21 January, one of its Catalinas located the Japanese fleet steaming for Rabaul and signalled a warning to the town's Australian defenders before being shot down by anti @-@ aircraft fire ; it was the squadron's first combat loss.

A week later, on 1 December 1941, the survivors were loaded onto the ship and taken to Port Hedland, where they were given food and medical treatment.

In the early hours of the following morning, the survivors were transferred to HMAS Sydney, which was in drydock at Fremantle.

After an uneventful voyage, the survivors arrived in Sydney on 8 December 1941, and were met by a crowd of well-wishers.

On the evening of 9 December 1941, the survivors were taken to the home of their commanding officer, Rear Admiral J.M. "Jack the Ripper" Macquarie, who took them to his home in Balgowlah.

Macquarie was a keen sportsman and enjoyed hunting, fishing and rowing. He had two sons, one of whom was killed in World War I.

The survivors spent the next few days at Balgowlah, where they were treated to a dinner of venison and other delicacies.

On the morning of 10 December 1941, the survivors were taken to a hotel in Sydney, where they were entertained by the hotel's proprietor, Mr and Mrs H.C. Withers.

Withers' son, John, was an Australian War Memorial (AWM) serviceman who had served in the South African War of Independence

prefix_text: <|endoftext|> In response to the threat of invasion at Port Moresby, Nos. 11 and 20 Squadrons moved to Bowen, Queensland, on 7 May 1942.
reference_text: They were soon attacking Japanese targets in Lae, Salamaua and Rabaul. By 1 July, No. 20 Squadron's strength was six Catalinas and 175 personnel, out of a planned establishment of nine aircraft and 415 personnel. Its prime responsibility in early 1942 was maritime reconnaissance as far as New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, and New Caledonia ; the latter half of the year saw a greater focus on night bombing. Now comprising 252 officers and men, the squadron relocated to Cairns on 11 November 1942. From Cairns it continued to conduct reconnaissance, anti @-@ submarine and occasional bombing operations over the waters around New Guinea. Between December 1942 and March 1943, No. 20 Squadron's aircraft flew a total of 9 @,@ 629 hours and dropped 227 tons of bombs. The squadron's role changed in June 1943 when it commenced mine @-@ laying operations over the Netherlands East Indies and the Philippines, though it continued to make some bombing raids and supply drops.

The Zapatistas fought back, and after a few years of fighting, the Conquistadores were forced to retreat.
